li: Java
Identify sensitive pages. Make a list of all pages that handle sensitive information, including all pages that use authentication or authorization features.

Enable SSL for each folder containing sensitive pages. The exact instructions for doing so are different for different web servers. Use the web server administration interface or edit the server configuration files to enable SSL for all folders containing sensitive pages.

Redirect non-SSL requests to SSL-protected pages. The exact instructions for doing so are different for different web servers. Use the web server administration interface or edit the server configuration files to redirect non-SSL requests to SSL-protected pages.

p: Require SSL for all private pages.
SSL should be used to protect all pages that handle sensitive data, including all pages that use authentication or authorization features, to prevent authentication hijacking.

The simplest approach for enabling SSL for all sensitive pages is to use SSL for the entire site. Enabling SSL for the entire site may require additional computing resources, so for performance reasons, it may be acceptable to enable SSL only for sensitive pages. To enable SSL only for sensitive pages:
Identify sensitive pages. Make a list of all pages that handle sensitive information, including all pages that use authentication or authorization features.

Enable SSL for each folder containing sensitive pages. The exact instructions for doing so are different for different web servers. Use the web server administration interface or edit the server configuration files to enable SSL for all folders containing sensitive pages.

Redirect non-SSL requests to SSL-protected pages. The exact instructions for doing so are different for different web servers. Use the web server administration interface or edit the server configuration files to redirect non-SSL requests to SSL-protected pages.

html:
Applies to

  • Java

What to Do

Require SSL for all private pages.

Why

SSL should be used to protect all pages that handle sensitive data, including all pages that use authentication or authorization features, to prevent authentication hijacking.

How

The simplest approach for enabling SSL for all sensitive pages is to use SSL for the entire site. Enabling SSL for the entire site may require additional computing resources, so for performance reasons, it may be acceptable to enable SSL only for sensitive pages. To enable SSL only for sensitive pages:

  1. Identify sensitive pages. Make a list of all pages that handle sensitive information, including all pages that use authentication or authorization features.

  2. Enable SSL for each folder containing sensitive pages. The exact instructions for doing so are different for different web servers. Use the web server administration interface or edit the server configuration files to enable SSL for all folders containing sensitive pages.

  3. Redirect non-SSL requests to SSL-protected pages. The exact instructions for doing so are different for different web servers. Use the web server administration interface or edit the server configuration files to redirect non-SSL requests to SSL-protected pages.

Java Communication Security Guidelines

  • Encrypt Communication Links
  • Protect Sensitive Data Over the Network
  • Use SSL
  • Use SSL for All Sensitive Pages
  • Use SSL When Transmitting Credentials
  • Use Valid SSL Certificates
  • Use Only Strong SSL Algorithms
  • Do Not Cache Sensitive Data
  • Do Not Place Sensitive Data in Parameters

  • SSL Is Used for All Sensitive Pages
